body: Hi, I don't mind taking a look at this. If you are allowed to share your data (which you indicate towards in your issue) you can send it to me at m.middlehurst@uea.ac.uk, else some data characteristics such as the size would be helpful. How are you loading/formatting the data prior to fitting?

Could it be because the dataset is too big?

By the way, I'd like to ask will the model be trained exactly the same way if we fit it with successive chunks of the dataset vs. fitting directly the the whole dataset in one call function call?
(My question applies to these especially: TimeSeriesForestClassifier, SupervisedTimeSeriesForest, CanonicalIntervalForest, DrCIF, RandomIntervalSpectralEnsemble)
Calling fit will overwrite any previous fit calls. Probably some quirk with threading/n_jobs>1 and numba, but not taken a look yet.
Okay I have sent you the dataset and notebook to reproduce the issue by email. thanks!

Seems to be a numba issue related to readonly arrays: https://github.com/numba/numba/issues/3070#issue-337198698

The solution might be:

```python
x = np.array(...)
x.setflags(write=True)
```

thanks @patrickzib, we were just looking at this and were wondering if it were just np.median/numba related or a wider issue with interference with the disk writing used in mmap.  One solution (from @dguijo) was to set 
fit = Parallel(n_jobs=self._threads_to_use, mmap_mode='w+')

I'm just concerned that by making the mmap writable by all threads, they will interfere. This would happen if, for example, first process had not finished writing to the temp file before second looks to see if the mmap is there. It also requires changing a lot of files for a bug localised on median (it now seems, thanks to that thread). 

Another solution is to just not make median a numba operation.

Just to confirm, replacing the `median` method in `sktime\utils\numba\stats.py` with the above code allows me to run `DrCIF` with `n_jobs=4` on the data provided by @henrydeclety. With the previous method, this crashed with the same error as the original issue.

(2) may just shift the problem elsewhere, (3) doesnt work, still crashes. I roughly profiled (4) for run time: its not actually faster than (2) but safer, so favoured solution is (4). I'm just running it on FaceDetection
We can try, but I think the call to set flags on X throws an error. I'll look in more detail tomorrow
